page.title: 06Christy Towels of Manchester
page.content: The factory was built in 1830 and was opened in 1837. It was a shirt factory to begin with. About 340 people work there. They make 50,000 towels a week. Cotton, yarn, trimmings and labels are used in the making of towels. The yarn comes from Portugal, Spain, Russia and Turkey, and the trimmings come from Switzerand. Tools used in the manufacturing processes are scissors, reed hooks, snips, electric shears and knotters. Machines are used too. The workers do not have to wear overalls, but they are allowed to if they want. The weaving is noisy and people who work on the weaving machines have to wear pops which are a kind of ear muff for protecting their ears. Christys only sell their goods in Britain. The canal used to be used for transport but now it is used for power.
